University of the West Indies Logo

AgriNeTT focuses on integrating ICT to improve the operations within the Agricultural sector of Trinidad and Tobago. The project is a collaborative effort of the Department of Computing and Information Technology at The University of the West Indies, The Faculty of Food and Agriculture at UWI, and various farmers’ representative organizations.

The National Agricultural Marketing and Development Corporation (NAMDEVCO) of Trinidad and Tobago is a major partner in the development and execution of the AgriNeTT project and has continued to provide tremendous support for the development of the AgriExprenseTT mobile application.

At the beginning of the application the user is presented a menu of options. A common starting point is to purchase items as we must first buy the resources needed to begin planting our crops. Each time a purchase is made, the user enters the information by selecting “Purchase”.

Crops are managed in cycles. A cycle is a single planting of crop in a given time. Therefore if the same crop is planted on two different days and on different portions of land it should be treated as separate cycles.

When purchasing a new item, you must select a category, a resource, (the item you are purchasing) how you are buying that resource, the quantity and cost. First begin by selecting the resource desired. The list of resources within the system is specified in the image above.

Within this example we select the Fertilizer resource. (As shown in the image above) After selecting the Fertilizer category, the system displays a list of all possible choices of fertilizers applicable within Trinidad and Tobago. If an option is missing, users can add new fertilizers through the "Manage Data" section of the application.

After choosing the specific fertilizer, the amount (number) of Fertilizer (resource) and its respective cost must be specified. When completed the system will show the available resource that a farmer will have based on their records.

Though we looked at Fertilizers within this example, there are different type of resources (therefore expenses) within the system. The diagram (image above) offers an explanation of the various expenses within the application.

The purchases made earlier now have to be allocated to the crops that you are planting. The entire purchase or a part of the purchase can be allocated to a crop cycle. Our next step is to create the crop cycle. When ‘create new cycle’ is selected we are presented with the list of crops (image above).
After selecting the crop to be planted in this cycle, we must specify the general size of land that the commodity will be planted on.
After selecting the type of land, we specify the total land and the date when the planting will begin.
After completing the creation of the cycle, the overview screen of the crop cycle is presented.

Each time something that was purchased is used in a crop cycle, that expense (or part of it) must be allocated to the crop cycle. This is done through the ‘manage resources’ menu item. Upon selection you are presented with a list of crop cycles. These crop cycles are displayed in order of time planted. Therefore the most recent crop cycle will appear first.

This application is designed to track the expenses of the crop cycle and not everything that you buy; as such the application calculates and adds cost on what you use in a crop cycle.Therefore you must use from what you\'ve purchased

As seen in fig 1.8 you are given the option to \'use more\' of something in your crop cycle, upon selection, you are presented with fig 1.9 where you select which of the items you have purchased you are going to use from. Note that the colours correspond to a category (In fig 1.9, green is Planting material and blue is fertilizers, while purple in fig 2.0 is chemical where you actually specify the usage.

You can change the unit of measurement you are using underneath \'Type of use\' e.g. you can buy in litres (Lt) and use milliliters (ml).You must then enter the amount you are using, in fig 2.0 the person is using 400 ml. Underneath the label \'Use\' there is some text that shows the details of what you are going to use, every time you hit the button \'calculate\', the app will calculate how much money will using the amount cost. If you select \'Use it!\' you are brought back to fig1.8 but the information would be updated to reflect the use of your purchase.

Hiring labour is very similar to purchasing a new material as you have to select who you\'re hiring (similar what you\'re actually purchasing), how are you paying them e.g. hourly (similar to the quantifier) and finally how much they work for and the total cost.
The difference is in the option to select if the labour is used for one cycle or many cycles, this means is the person you hire going to work for one or many different cycles.

When you select \‘hire labour\’ you are presented with the view in fig 2.1. After you select who you\'re hiring you are presented with fig 2.2 where you must select if the individual is working for one cycle or many cycle. If you select one cycle you are presented with fig 2.3
After if you select many cycles or when you select which cycle the individual is working for, you are presented with fig 2.4 and then 2.5 to confirm hiring.
The user is then presented with the overview of the current cycle details.

Did you make a mistake when you bought something? Did you make a mistake when you created a crop cycle? Are we missing a resource that you bought?, that’s okay because you can add, edit and delete data as you please. As seen here when you select manage data in fig 1.0, you are presented with this screen that allows you to perform editing, deletion and addition

Edit Data: Here you can select either a crop cycle or a purchase and change the details how you like. fig 2.7 show the screen where you select what you would like to edit with cycles on the left tab, purchases on the right, fig 2.8 shows editing a crop cycle and fig 2.9 shows editing a purchase.

Delete Data: Select Delete Data in fig 2.6, at which point you are presented with a 3(three) tab views, (cycles, purchases, resources) fig 3.0. All you have to do is select what you would like to delete and confirm by clicking yes when the dialogue box appears

Note when deleting a cycle it replenishes the purchases It used from the same applies with a purchase, when deleting a purchase it undoes all the uses any cycles made from it, therefore if you delete a cycle it is as if it never used the purchase, and if you delete a purchase it is as if the cycle never used from it.
If you delete a resource that is the crop of a crop cycle, the cycle is deleted, likewise if you have purchased the resource that you are deleting the purchase will be deleted as well.

The follow list contains information that relates to what is stored by the system and provides options that will allow you to backup and sync your information online to increase the reliability of the system
Sorry you haven\'t purchased anything to use
Will he/she be working on one cycle (crop) or working on multiple cycles (crops)?

The application allows user to generate a report that can be utilized in most computers today. This allow farmers to have greater flexibility with keeping records and store the records in formats that can be submitted to other agencies such as the Agricultural based financial institutions.
AgriExpense is a mobile application that will keep track of some of the input of the production process
Cycles represent each individual plot of land that is planted. Each individual planting is usually represented as a crop cycle.
Purchases represents the total cost of the items purchased. As materials from the purchase is used during the life of the crop, the fraction of the cost will be added to the cycle.
Select how often you want to be notified.
Please select the following criteria to determine how often and at what time you will like to be notified to enter data.
